Fifty years ago this week on an Alabama bus, Rosa Parks refused to give up her seat to a white man.
The action led to the Montgomery bus boycott and eventually ended segregation on city buses, but in the state which fostered the civil rights movement, public transportation is now minimal.
As NPR's Kathy Lohr reports, citizens who benefited from Rosa Parks' action now face their own struggles with bus service.
This week's celebration of the 50th anniversary of the Montgomery bus boycott is a symbol for people across the country of how far cities have come since 1955.
(Singing) Come on up to the front of the bus, and I'll be riding up there.
In Montgomery, Alabama, thousands of children, black and white, walked together downtown, marching to the state Capitol in honor of Rosa Parks and the gains of the civil rights movement.
Patricia Wilson was one of those who walked with the children.
She says conditions are better across the country than in Alabama.

Sometimes it seems that everything that was fought for as far as the buses are concerned has just gone down the drain in a sense because, I mean, so many people fought for this for the buses, but it's not being carried out.
Alabama is one of only five states that does not fund its public transportation systems.
The reason dates back to 1932 when the president of General Motors created a national group to lobby state legislatures.
They wanted all gas taxes and road revenue to pay for building and maintaining roads and bridges.
In 1952, Alabamians passed a constitutional amendment to do just that.
For several years, a coalition of community groups, known as Alabama Arise, has been trying to change this in the Legislature.
Response has not been particularly good.
Ron Gilbert is a policy analyst with Alabama Arise.
Last year, a bill to get a measure on the ballot finally made it through committee but failed to go any further.
Public transportation is a serious problem.
It's a little unique when you've got a rural state like we have here in terms of trying to get folks to basic services they might need, to a doctor's office, to the grocery store, to a job.
So we have really unique special problems we think here in Alabama in terms of transportation and have a system that's not responsive to the needs of the people.
As of 2000, about 1.3 million people who live in rural Alabama had no access to public transit at all.

In Montgomery, there are about a dozen routes, but one problem for those riding the system comes down to being able to get from point A to point B on time, especially when it involves transferring buses.

That's all.
